meshes.name: Cerebral White Matter (Left)
meshes.description: The wiring that connects different parts of my left hemisphere. Since I'm left-handed, this side handles language processing while my right hemisphere takes over for fine motor control.

meshes.name: Cerebral Cortex (Left)
meshes.description: The wrinkly outer layer where most of the heavy lifting happens. This side likely handles the bulk of my language processing, including writing blog posts and taking notes in Obsidian.

meshes.name: Lateral Ventricle (Left)
meshes.description: A fluid-filled cavity that cushions my brain and helps clear metabolic waste. Basically internal plumbing.

meshes.name: Cerebellar White Matter (Left)
meshes.description: The communication cables running through my left cerebellum, connecting it to the brainstem and the rest of the motor system.

meshes.name: Cerebellar Cortex (Left)
meshes.description: Coordinates the right side of my body. Handles balance and motor learning for actions like walking through hospital corridors.

meshes.name: Thalamus (Left)
meshes.description: The relay station that routes sensory information up to my cortex. Everything I see, hear, or feel passes through here first.

meshes.name: Caudate Nucleus (Left)
meshes.description: Involved in planning and goal-directed behaviour. Probably lights up when I'm architecting a new coding project or planning my study schedule.

meshes.name: Putamen (Left)
meshes.description: Helps with motor control and forming habits. This is what makes typing and keyboard shortcuts feel automatic after enough repetition.

meshes.name: Globus Pallidus (Left)
meshes.description: The output hub of my basal ganglia. It fine-tunes movement by selectively inhibiting motor signals, helping me make smooth, controlled movements.

meshes.name: Third Ventricle
meshes.description: A narrow cerebrospinal fluid channel sitting between my two thalami. Part of the brain's internal circulation system.

meshes.name: Fourth Ventricle
meshes.description: Located between the brainstem and cerebellum. CSF flows through here before circulating around my spinal cord.

meshes.name: Brainstem
meshes.description: The core of my survival systems. Controls breathing, heart rate, sleep-wake cycles, and all the things I don't have to think about. Keeps me alive during long study sessions.

meshes.name: Hippocampus (Left)
meshes.description: Where new memories get formed. Does a lot of heavy lifting when I'm learning 585 medical conditions or remembering which patient had which presentation.

meshes.name: Amygdala (Left)
meshes.description: Processes emotions and flags things as important. Probably activates when I'm minutes away from scrubbing into surgery and realise I haven't looked up the procedure yet.

meshes.name: Nucleus Accumbens (Left)
meshes.description: The reward centre. This is what makes finally solving a bug or completing a condition in the Matrix feel satisfying.

meshes.name: Ventral Diencephalon (Left)
meshes.description: Contains the hypothalamus, which regulates hunger, thirst, temperature, and circadian rhythms. Responsible for reminding me to eat during long coding sessions.

meshes.name: Choroid Plexus (Left)
meshes.description: The tissue that produces cerebrospinal fluid. Secretes about 500ml of CSF per day to keep my brain floating and protected.

meshes.name: Cerebral White Matter (Right)
meshes.description: The wiring of my dominant hemisphere. As a left-hander, this side handles fine motor control, including the movements needed for writing and typing.

meshes.name: Cerebral Cortex (Right)
meshes.description: My dominant motor hemisphere since I'm left-handed. The motor cortex here controls my left hand. Also involved in spatial reasoning and visual processing.

meshes.name: Lateral Ventricle (Right)
meshes.description: Mirror of the left lateral ventricle. Contains cerebrospinal fluid that cushions and nourishes my brain.

meshes.name: Inferior Lateral Ventricle (Right)
meshes.description: The temporal horn of my right lateral ventricle, extending down alongside the hippocampus. Part of the CSF circulation system.

meshes.name: Cerebellar White Matter (Right)
meshes.description: White matter tracts connecting the right cerebellar cortex to the brainstem and beyond.

meshes.name: Cerebellar Cortex (Right)
meshes.description: Coordinates my left side, the dominant one. Handles the motor learning and fine coordination needed for left-handed tasks like writing in my Muji notebook.

meshes.name: Thalamus (Right)
meshes.description: The right relay station, filtering and routing sensory information to my cortex. Also plays a role in attention and alertness.

meshes.name: Caudate Nucleus (Right)
meshes.description: Part of the goal-directed behaviour system. Helps with planning sequences of actions and learning from feedback.

meshes.name: Putamen (Right)
meshes.description: Critical for left-hand motor control. Helps turn conscious movements into automatic habits through repetition.

meshes.name: Globus Pallidus (Right)
meshes.description: Output nucleus of my right basal ganglia. Sends inhibitory signals to fine-tune movement on my left side.

meshes.name: Hippocampus (Right)
meshes.description: Handles spatial memory and navigation. This side is more involved in remembering where things are, like the layout of the hospital or where I saved that file.

meshes.name: Amygdala (Right)
meshes.description: Processes emotional responses, especially fear and anxiety. The right amygdala is particularly active in detecting negative emotions and threats.

meshes.name: Nucleus Accumbens (Right)
meshes.description: Part of my reward circuitry. Works alongside its left counterpart to process motivation and make accomplishments feel worthwhile.

meshes.name: Ventral Diencephalon (Right)
meshes.description: Contains hypothalamic structures that regulate autonomic functions. Works with its left counterpart to maintain homeostasis.

meshes.name: Choroid Plexus (Right)
meshes.description: Vascular tissue that produces cerebrospinal fluid on the right side. Constantly manufacturing the fluid that keeps my brain afloat.

meshes.name: Corpus Callosum (Posterior)
meshes.description: The splenium, connecting my visual cortices across hemispheres. Lets both sides of my brain share what I'm looking at.

meshes.name: Corpus Callosum (Mid-Posterior)
meshes.description: Connects parietal regions across hemispheres. Important for integrating sensory information from both sides of my body.

meshes.name: Corpus Callosum (Central)
meshes.description: Connects my motor and sensory cortices across hemispheres. Helps coordinate bilateral movements.

meshes.name: Corpus Callosum (Mid-Anterior)
meshes.description: Links premotor areas across hemispheres. Helps both sides of my brain coordinate when planning complex movements.

meshes.name: Corpus Callosum (Anterior)
meshes.description: The genu, connecting my prefrontal cortices. Lets both hemispheres share executive functions, working memory, and decision-making.
